coredata.dc:description: Facilitated transport membranes for post-combustion carbon capture are one of the technologies to achieve efficient and large-scale capture. The central principle is to utilize the affinity of CO2 for the carrier to achieve efficient separation and to break the Robson upper bound. This paper reviews the progress of facilitated transport membranes research regarding polymer materials, principles, and problems faced at this stage. Firstly, we briefly introduce the transport mechanism of the facilitated transport membranes. Then the research progress of several major polymers used for facilitated transport membranes for CO2/N2 separation was presented in the past five years. Additionally, we analyze the primary challenges of facilitated transport membranes, including the influence of water, the effect of temperature, the saturation effect of the carrier, and the process configuration. Finally, we also delve into the challenges and competitiveness of facilitated transport membranes.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Facilitated transport membranes for post-combustion carbon capture are one of the technologies to achieve efficient and large-scale capture. The central principle is to utilize the affinity of CO2 for the carrier to achieve efficient separation and to break the Robson upper bound. This paper reviews the progress of facilitated transport membranes research regarding polymer materials, principles, and problems faced at this stage. Firstly, we briefly introduce the transport mechanism of the facilitated transport membranes. Then the research progress of several major polymers used for facilitated transport membranes for CO2/N2 separation was presented in the past five years. Additionally, we analyze the primary challenges of facilitated transport membranes, including the influence of water, the effect of temperature, the saturation effect of the carrier, and the process configuration. Finally, we also delve into the challenges and competitiveness of facilitated transport membranes.

ce:section.ce:para: Global climate change has caused adverse effects on various aspects of the ecological environment, including rising sea levels, compromised species integrity and survival, and increased risk of disease transmission [1–3]. Excessive CO2 emissions are among the primary factors contributing to global warming [4,5]. In December 2023, Dubai hosted the Conference of Parties (COP-28) noting the current difficulty in meeting the goals of the Paris Agreement set in 2015. In addition, the United Nations Environment Programme's (UNEP) Emissions Gap Report 2023 highlighted a worrying trend, with global temperatures projected to rise by 2.5–2.9 °C this century if the current trend continues [6,7]. Data from Fig. 1 , sourced from the Carbon Monitor. In recent years, except 2020 when it was impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, there has been an increasing trend in global annual CO2 emissions. These staggering figures highlight the urgent need to address CO2 emissions, underscoring the critical importance of CO2 capture as a response to this escalating environmental challenge.

The primary source of flue gas that originates from the combustion of fossil fuels and cement in industrial processes composition is very complex, including many pollutants [9,10]. In such a harsh environment, how to efficiently capture CO2 has become a challenge. There are many methods for capturing CO2, including absorption [11], adsorption [12], and ionic liquids [13]. However, most of the above methods are energy-intensive or cannot be implemented on a large scale in harsh environments, resulting in significant energy consumption and high-cost estimate [14]. Given these challenges, researchers have turned their attention to membranes. Membrane-based gas separation demonstrates significant potential and offers advantages such as reduced energy consumption and simplified operation [15,16]. Since 1970, polyester membrane and polyamide (PA) membrane have been used for gas separation. These membrane materials have good stability and separation performance. New high-performance materials, such as polyether ketone, polyimide, and fluorinated polymers, have also been applied to large-scale gas separation in industry in the following decades [16–18]. In addition, CO2-philic materials such as PEO also showed enormous potential [19,20].

In the field of polymer membrane separation technology, achieving a balance of selective permeability has always been a challenging problem to overcome. McKeown revised the latest upper bound data in 2019, which was based on experimental performance data of polymer membranes [21,22]. Although in recent years, the addition of Metal-Organic Frameworks (MOFs), Covalent-Organic Frameworks (COFs), and inorganic nanoparticles (Zeolites, Graphene Oxide (GO)) had enabled membranes to achieve excellent performance, surpassing the Robeson upper bound [23–27]. These membranes still lacked real flue gas testing and faced challenges in terms of scalability for large-scale production. Since the 1960s, researchers have extensively studied facilitated transport membranes (FTMs). This technology primarily utilizes the amino groups present in polymers as nucleophilic agents to attack the electrophilic CO2 in flue gas. The utilization of reversible acid-base reactions involving acidic gases and basic amino groups enhances the separation efficiency of CO2 gas within the membrane [15,28]. The CO2 is dissolved in the polymer, and the carrier in the polymer, such as an amino group, provides a reaction site where the CO2 “jumps” to accelerate the separation. A detailed description will be presented in Section 2. In recent years, large literature studies have focused on CO2 capture from flue gas and explored applications in natural gas, biogas, and synthetic gas purification [29–31]. In 2017, Hägg's team tested Polyvinylamine (PVAm)-based hollow fiber membranes at the Tiller plant and the Norcem cement plant in Norway, respectively, in which the permeate from a single layer of membranes both achieved CO2 purity of more than 60% and demonstrated stability of performance in an environment where contaminants were present [32,33]. In 2019, Ho's team conducted a pilot project on CO2 capture at the NCCC in the United States, demonstrating membrane materials with stability exceeding 500 h and no significant impurity deposition [34]. Overall, the results achieved with facilitated transport membranes indicate their feasibility in treating actual flue gases. Several polymers that have recently been used for FTMs are shown in Table 1 .

This study comprehensively reviews advancements in post-combustion carbon capture using FTMs over the past five years. Initially, it elucidates the fundamental theory underpinning gas transport mechanisms in FTMs. Subsequently, the paper discusses polymer membrane materials that have been prevalent in the past five years. Finally, common issues in FTMs, such as maintaining moisture, carrier saturation phenomena, and process configuration, are summarized.

Gas separation membranes predominantly employ polymers as their primary materials. The gas separation mechanism in polymer membranes is commonly explained through the solution diffusion model, in which the separation process is governed by the solubility and diffusivity of the gas as it passes through the polymer membrane. As shown in Eqs. (1) and (2), the gas permeability (P) is determined by the multiplication of the kinetic diffusion coefficient (D) and the thermodynamic solubility coefficient (S). In FTMs, the primary transport process involves not only the solution diffusion mechanism but also the reversible reaction between the target gas and the reaction carriers [52,53].

In Eq. (2), the first term on the right-hand side of the equation is the CO2 solution-diffusion mechanism, while the second term represents the facilitated transport.

Amino-containing polymers that have been extensively studied for FTMs are PVAm, PA, and polyethyleneimine (PEI). Amino-containing polymers and CO2 have a high affinity for each other. As illustrated in Fig. 2 , CO2 has a polarized structure where the oxygen atoms are more electronegative than the carbon atom [54], resulting in an electron deficiency at the carbon atom, making it an electrophilic reagent (Lewis acid). On the other hand, the nitrogen atom in the amino group of the polymer has a lone pair of electrons, making it a nucleophilic reagent (Lewis base) [55]. According to Lewis's acid-base theory, the amino group acts as a nucleophile and attacks the electrophilic carbon atom of CO2, leading to the formation of a carbamate (for primary and secondary amines) or carbamic acid (for tertiary amines) intermediate [56–60]. This reversible interaction is the primary driving force behind the high affinity of amino-containing polymers for CO2, which is crucial for applications in carbon capture and storage and gas separation processes.

As shown in Eq. (3) and (4), CO2 reacts with either primary or secondary amine as a nucleophilic reagent, forming an unstable amphoteric ion, which continues to react with either primary or secondary amine to form a stable carbamate ion. This process that requires 1 mol of CO2 and 2 mol of primary amine [61,62].
Image 1

The second type, as shown in Eq. (5), is a tertiary amine, where the formation of amphoteric ions is hindered by the fact that tertiary amine cannot provide protons. Therefore, the involvement of water is necessary for the reaction between tertiary amines and CO2 [63]. Water can undergo a reaction with CO2 to generate carbonic acid, subsequently interacting with the tertiary amine group. Only 1 mol of tertiary amine is required to start the reaction process. Thus, tertiary amine provides a higher loading of CO2, but the reaction rate is slow due to the weak ionization of hydrogen ions from H2CO3 [64].

PVAm is commonly produced through the free radical polymerization of N-vinylformamide (NVF), subsequent acid hydrolysis, and finally, anion exchange treatment [65]. Several researchers have synthesized high molecular weight PVAm by inverse emulsion polymerization (IEP) technology [35], which is shown in Fig. 3 . Compared to the other amine-containing polymers, PVAm possesses the highest concentration of primary amine functional groups [66], making it a strong candidate for FTMs.

Penetration of the selective layer of thin-film composite (TFC) membranes into the support layer has always been an important problem, which not only leads to the formation of defects in the selective layer but also increases the resistance to gas transmission [68,69]. In recent years, the introduction of gutter layers (e.g., Polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS)) has been used to solve the problem, but has greatly increased the thickness of the membranes [70,71]. The synthesis of high molecular weight, highly viscous PVAm through the IEP method has effectively reduced the penetration to the substrate. The increased PVAm of the polymer helps to increase the viscosity of the solution, which in turn improves the stability of the membrane. Ho's team synthesized a high molecular weight PVAm by using the IEP method [35]. They found that the viscosity of PVAm increased linearly at molecular weights below 12.7 MDA, and the membrane thickness decreased, which led to an increase in membrane permeance, as shown in Fig. 4 (a). They also introduced a hydrophilic mobile carrier, piperazine glycine (PG), which further increased the separation performance of the membranes, as shown in Fig. 4(b). This suggested that the high molecular weight PVAm enhanced the stability of the membrane and also contributed to the uniform dispersion of the mobile carrier in the membrane matrix.

The membrane performance improvement by introducing mobile carrier into PVAm matrix was also demonstrated by the other works from Ho's group [37]. FTMs using alanine (Ala), lysine (Lys) and proline (Pro) as mobile carriers were designed. The membrane showed higher performance. Compared to the pure PVAm membrane with permeance of 519 GPU and selectivity of 81, the synthetic membrane containing PVAm (35 wt%) and PZEA (2-(1-piperazinyl)ethylamine)-Pro (65 wt%) showed a CO2 permeance of 936 GPU at 57 °C and a 193 selectivity of CO2/N2. To demonstrate the potential of PVAm/amino acid salts containing membranes for industrial applications, Ho's team fabricated 1.4 m2 spiral-wound (SW) module with PVAm/PZEA-Sar TFC membranes [34], which were tested in situ at NCCC in Wilsonville, USA. As shown in Fig. 5 , a good stability of 500 h in the actual flue gas was demonstrated. Moreover, there was no obvious deposition of particles such as Cr, AS and Se on the membrane. The experimental results showed that the membrane demonstrated excellent potential for scaling-up applications. The membrane's high stability and resistance to contamination also provided a basis for the future design of large-size membranes.

Besides the incorporation of the mobile carrier into the PVAm matrix, other polymers or inorganic fillers were also added to reduce the crystallinity of PVAm membranes [40,72]. Wang's team synthesized PVAm/polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) composite membranes by precisely controlling the reaction conditions to reduce the crystallinity of PVAm [36]. The CO2 permeance was 726 GPU and the selectivity of CO2/N2 was 55 at 0.5 MPa, respectively. And a 1 m wide defect-free composite membrane was successfully prepared, which demonstrated the potential for scaling-up. Li and colleagues used the same method to synthesize PVAm and added carbon nanotubes (CNTs) to the membrane to increase the free volume of the membrane, and good separation performance was also obtained [39]. The PVAm/PANI@CNTs-GO MMMS prepared by Wang's group were shown in Fig. 6 . The superior layer spacing of GO provided a transport channel for CO2. CNTs helped to reduce the crystallinity of PVAm. Because both PANI and PVAM were rich in amino groups, the stability was enhanced by the hydrogen bonding between PVAm and PANI@CNTs-GO [38]. At 25 °C and 1 bar, the permeance of CO2 was 264 GPU, and the selectivity of CO2/N2 was 149.8. In addition, they also prepared MMMs consisting of PVAm and an amorphous material, Metakaolin (MK) [40]. Intermolecular hydrogen bonds were formed due to the tetrahedral structure of MK, comprising SI–O and Al–O bonds. The separation performance of the membranes was stable in the tests up to 300 h.

Since the 1980s, interfacial polymerization (IP) has been widely used to fabricate PA-based membranes for desalination and gas separation [73,74]. PA is rich in polar groups, such as hydroxyl, amine, and carboxyl. The molecular chains of PA are closely arranged, which has a high glass transition temperature and thermal stability [75,76]. Nevertheless, due to its lower free volume, it generally exhibits higher selectivity and lower permeance. Researchers improved the permeance of PA membranes through polymer copolymerization or combination with inorganic nanoparticles. In addition, the optimization of reaction conditions of IP improved the performance of PA membranes [42,44,77].

Conventional polymer membranes based on PA rarely exhibit high gas permeance and CO2/N2 selectivity in the gas separation studies. To break Roberson upper bound, Li et al. prepared PA-based membranes for CO2 separation by IP with (mono-(6-ethylenediamine-6-deoxy)-β-cyclodextrin) MEDβCD fillers, as shown in Fig. 7 [41]. The polar groups (hydroxyl groups) contained in MEDβCD easily form hydrogen bonds with water molecules, which enhanced CO2 transfer. As shown in Fig. 8 (a) and (b), the permeance of CO2 increased gradually with increasing concentration of MEDβCD solution. At a mass of 0.4 of MEDβCD in the aqueous phase, the prepared membranes had high CO2 permeance and excellent CO2/N2 selectivity, which satisfied the feasibility of CO2 separation. The prepared membranes were able to maintain excellent stability in a 100 h continuous gas test. The improvement of membrane performance by introducing β-CD into the PA matrix has also been demonstrated in Wang's team [142]. They prepared a PA-based composite membrane by using biomimetic hydroxypropyl-β-cyclodextrin (Hβ-CD) as the nanofiller. The introduction of Hβ-CD molecules facilitated CO2 transport. The membranes showed excellent CO2 separation performance when the Hβ-CD concentration was at 0.20. The permeance of CO2 and the CO2/N2 selectivity reached 2792 GPU and 173, respectively.

Regulating and optimizing the process of IP was also a way to improve the performance of PA-based membrane. Zhang et al. prepared a zinc-containing PA TFC membrane using the ion implantation method shown in Fig. 9 [42]. 0.1 wt% Zn ions were added in the IP preparation procedure to boost the local concentration of amine monomers surrounding the zinc ions. The membrane contained a large number of free amine and tertiary amine groups, increasing the membrane's affinity for CO2 and promoting its absorption without affecting CO2 selectivity. Compared to pure PA membranes, the CO2 permeance increased 75.2%. Li et al. used trimesoyl chloride (TMC) as the organic phase monomer and piperazine (PIP) as the aqueous phase monomer. The addition of carboxymethyl chitosan (CMC) to the aqueous phase modulated the IP process. As shown in Fig. 10 , the addition of CMC altered the rate of diffusion of PIP into the organic phase, resulting in the formation of a Turing structure [43]. As a result, more reaction sites were generated, and the water-swellable CMC enhanced the facilitated transport efficiency of CO2 and amino groups. In addition, the carboxyl groups on the CMC chain enhanced the antioxidant properties of the membranes. The stability was maintained for 100 h in simulated flue gas tests. Similarly, Jiao et al. also prepared Turing-structured PA membranes by adding UiO-66-NH2 (Zr-based MOF) to the aqueous phase [77]. UiO-66-NH2 similarly reduced the diffusion of the aqueous phase, which produced a localized interfacial reaction. The membranes exhibited enhanced CO2 permeance compared to pure PA membranes.

Among the methods to improve the performance of PA membranes, the addition of nanoparticles was notable. The MMMs prepared by adding porous nanoparticles possessed excellent separation performance [78–81]. However, these nanoparticles had weak adhesion to the selective layer, leading to a tendency for nanoparticle agglomeration, making it challenging to effectively control their position within selective layer [82,83]. Moreover, the nanoparticles deposited on the surface of the selective layer were difficult to provide an effective gas channel region. A breakthrough in this domain came from the work of Li et al. They prepared a PA-based thin-film nanocomposite membrane by effectively swelling the intermediate layer PDMS through Swelling-controlled Nanofiller Positioning [84]. The ZIF-8 was pre-attached to the PSF, and then TMC was added to enhance the homogeneous dispersion of ZIF-8 during the IP process. The unreacted PDMS can effectively restrict the migration of ZIF-8, ensuring that the nanoparticles were uniformly distributed near the surface of the support layer (i.e., the lower region of the selective layer). The gas transport performance was enhanced. Among the strategies to reduce nanoparticle agglomeration, Li et al. designed a filtration-spraying method [85]. As shown in Fig. 11 , firstly, by depositing PEI-ZIF-6 on the substrate, and then spraying Pebax. The polymer was allowed to fill up the voids between fillers during solvent evaporation, which effectively suppressed the agglomeration of nanofillers. In addition, they used this method to demonstrate other nanoparticles, all of which also improved the CO2 separation performance.

In addition to the above two polymers, PEI, poly (allylamine) (PAA) and chitosan (CS) have also been used as polymers for the preparation of FTMs. Due to limitations of low molecular weight or high crystallinity, these were often used to prepare polymer blend membranes with other polymers. Moreover, these polymer membranes were less reported in the last five years. The following is a brief review.

PEI is a low-cost, hyperbranched, hydrophilic polymer with significant application potential [86]. Recent studies have shown that it was possible to prepare blend membranes from PEI and hydrophilic polymers. The addition of hydrophilic polymers was expected to improve the separation performance of the membranes [87,88]. Helberg et al. blended the hydrophilic polymers PVP/PVA with PEI as a carrier for the FTMs to promote carbon dioxide separation [46]. The results showed a doubling of CO2 permeance compared to the pure polymer membrane. More importantly, PVA and PVP are non-toxic, which aligns with the green chemistry concept.

PAA is mainly composed of primary amine. However, PAA was unable to form a stable membrane under dry conditions [89]. It was usually blended with other polymers as a fixed carrier. In 2012, Ho's team applied PAA-based sterically hindered amines as fixed carriers in membranes for the first time [62]. Subsequently, the excellent performance of bit-blocking PAA was confirmed by Janakiram’s group [49]. They synthesized PVA and sterically-hindered PAA blend membranes using a one-pot method. Hydrophilic PEG was also used as an additive. The CO2 permeance was enhanced by about 50% without changing the selectivity of the pure PAA.

CS is a natural bio-polymer. It has excellent stability. Parasad et al. prepared PAA/CS blended membranes [90]. The CO2 permeance and CO2/N2 selectivity were both improved by more than 3 times compared to pure CS [50]. In addition, Borgohain et al. found that Carboxymethyl Chitosan (CMC) had a superior water retention capacity and higher solubility for easy membrane preparation. They prepared Poly (amidoamine) (PAMAM)/CMC blend membranes that maintained 98 GPU CO2 permeance and 149 CO2/N2 selectivity at a high temperature of 90 °C [51].

Ionic liquids (ILs) have attracted widespread attention due to their low volatility, high thermal stability, and strong affinity for CO2 [91–94]. Moreover, the combination of ILs with membranes to form facilitated transport ionic liquid membranes has been reported extensively in the field of carbon capture [95–97]. The following is a brief review.

Among the strategies to optimize CO2 separation performance, most researchers have focused on increasing the permeance of CO2, while reducing the permeance of N2 is also a viable approach. Recently, as shown in Fig. 12 (a), Wu and Xu's team developed three fluorinated ionic ILs containing diamine cations, which were fixed on PES to form ionic liquid membranes. 3-(dimethylamino)-1-propylamine fluoride ([DMAPAH][F]) facilitated CO2 transport due to its amino groups while salting out effect on N2 inhibits it diffusion. Wherein, the ionic liquid membrane of [DMAPAH][F] had a permeance of CO2 of up to 2572 barrers and a selectivity of up to 774 at 0.1 bar [98]. Furthermore, as shown in Fig. 12(b), they also investigated the synthesis of ECH-amine-based crosslinked primary ionic liquids by reacting with 3-(dimethylamino)-1-propylamine methoxyacetate ([DMAPAH][MOAc]) using epichlorohydrin as a crosslinking agent. It was also proposed to adjust the molar ratio of carboxylic acid to amine to optimize the CO2 separation performance [99]. In studies to reduce the permeance of N2, Kang's team also made a discovery. They thermally synthesized CrO3 particles using 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate (BMIM-BF4). The free imidazolium ions in BMIM-BF4 facilitated CO2 transport. CrO3 particles inhibited N2 molecules, thus improving the separation performance [100].

In recent years, ionic liquid gel membranes have also gained much attention due to their excellent gas transport properties and separation performance [101–104]. Some new amino acid ILs have also been developed for CO2 capture [105,106]. More CO2-philic materials (i.e., ether-based, imidazolyl-based) have also been used in ionic liquid membranes [107–109]. However, the ILs technology still faces many challenges in the field of CO2 separation, such as cost issues, regeneration, and stability, which require further research and improvement. More excellent discussions of ionic liquid-based FTMs can be found in these reviews [110–113].

ce:section.ce:section-title: Effect of water on FTMs performance
ce:section.ce:para:
In FTMs, maintaining appropriate water content presents a significant challenge. As shown in equation (6), water is involved in the reaction that promotes CO2 transport across the membrane and accelerates the transport of CO2. In addition, the hydrophilic groups in the membrane adsorbed more water molecules, making the membrane more permeable and increasing the transport channel of CO2. So water can improve the separation performance of CO2 through the amino-promoted transport membrane [114,115].

Expanding on this, Casadei et al. used PVAm (45 wt%) as a stationary carrier, arginine (27.5 wt%) as a mobile carrier, and added carboxymethylated nano fibrillated cellulose (27.5 wt%) for enhanced membrane stability [116]. The prepared membranes maintained a CO2/N2 selectivity of around 50 when the relative humidity (RH) was increased from 90% RH to 100% RH, while the permeance increased from 180 to 340 bar. Indicating that the RH had an effect on facilitating the transfer of the membranes, partly due to the hydrophilic of PVAm and arginine. The arginine was considered the most hydrophilic of the amino acids [117], and it further enhanced water flow.

Similarly emphasizing the role of RH and hydrophilic materials, Belaissaoui and colleagues explored the combined effects of polyallylamine (PAA) with other compounds. They prepared hybrid immobilized carrier membranes using PAA with polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) (10 wt%) and graphene oxide (0.2 wt%) [118]. Fig. 13 showed the effect of RH on membrane performance. Both CO2 and N2 permeance increased with RH. The increase in RH enhanced the water content in the membrane and promoted the rate at which the amine transported CO2. However, at RH levels exceeding 70%, the water content caused the membrane to swell excessively, which increased its free volume and resulted in decreased selectivity. Therefore, choosing an appropriate RH is also a key factor in enhancing membrane performance. The Ho's team used membranes made from Lupamin® (PVAm and sodium formate), which showed better separation performance than membranes made from pure PVAm [115]. Probably due to the fact that the salt retains water better than PVAm, the process of facilitating transport was enhanced.

In previous studies, the impact of water on the separation performance of amino-containing polymer membranes remained ambiguous. However, recent work by Pate et al. has shed light on this issue. They characterized the molecular structure of PVAm polymer membranes by infrared spectroscopy [61]. The results showed that CO2 mainly moved in PVAm as amino formate species. The formation of amino formate species required water in the feed gas mixture. Amino formate species were not formed in the absence of water. The reaction mechanism shown in Fig. 14 indicated the important role of water in the membrane. However, the mechanism had a limitation in that hydroxide ions could also react with CO2 to generate bicarbonate. It was not clear whether the reaction was between the amino group and CO2. Therefore, further investigation is needed. In addition, Yang et al. used a mathematical modeling method called “tanks-in-series”. It was also verified that a decrease in water vapor concentration in the membrane would cause a decrease in permeance [119].

Water plays a critical role in FTMs. The effect of water on transport membranes depends on the factors such as membrane composition, structure, porosity, surface chemistry, and operating conditions [119,120]. Water can improve the CO2 selectivity and flux of transport membranes, but it can also lead to degradation, aging, or deactivation of the membranes. In addition to this, the aspects of dissolution, swelling, polarity and hydrophilicity all have a unique effect on transport. Therefore, it is also important for future studies to explore the mechanism of water action and regulation in FTMs.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Effect of pressure on FTMs performance
ce:section.ce:para: Pressure plays a crucial role in membrane performance. As feed pressure increases, the polymer becomes denser, which can limit gas permeation. Additionally, CO2 exhibits a plasticizing effect at high pressures, causing alterations in the polymer chain structure. Notably, for FTMs, the carrier saturation phenomenon becomes significant at elevated pressures, leading to reduce membrane performance [121–123].

Several studies have delved into the intricate effects of pressure on membrane properties and behavior. For instance, Wang and colleagues conducted a study on DNMDAm-CD/TMC membranes to explore the separation of CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 gas mixtures [39]. They found as the feed pressure increased from 0.11 to 1.0 MPa, CO2 permeance decreased from approximately 2225 GPU to 450 GPU. While these observations revealed light on carrier saturation, another dimension was added by Xu and colleagues, who not only investigated the effect of varying pressures but also delved deeper into the transport mechanisms. They elucidated the presence of two transport mechanisms at low pressures. They prepared pure PVAm membranes of varying thicknesses and investigated the effect of different CO2 feed pressures on membrane performance [124]. Fig. 15 (a) illustrated the relationship between CO2 flux and pressure. With 10 kPa as the data analysis point, there was a non-linear increase before 10 kPa and a linear increase after 10 kPa, indicating that there were two transport mechanisms in the membrane. The CO2 passed through the PVAm membrane only through the solution-diffusion mechanism after 10 kPa due to the carrier saturation phenomenon. Fig. 15(b) demonstrated that as the feed pressure increased, the CO2 permeance decreased. The same phenomenon was observed in the development of PVAm/PZEA-Sar based composite membranes by Han's work [125], as shown in Fig. 16 (a). They also observed similar carrier saturation phenomena. They found that CO2 flux increased linearly with increasing feed pressure, while N2 showed a linear increasing trend. It was also shown that there may be two transport mechanisms. In addition, as shown in Fig. 16(b), they found that the CO2 permeance has not changed significantly with increasing feed pressure while keeping the CO2 partial pressure constant. It showed that the carrier saturation is related to the CO2 partial pressure and not only the feed pressure.

To delve deeper into the carrier saturation effect, they also investigated carrier saturation by using surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) to characterize the transport of CO2 through PVAm membranes. In the analysis of Raman spectra under different CO2 pressures, several peaks corresponding to amino formate groups were observed in the 1076-1693 cm−1 range. Fig. 17 (a) showed that the peak intensities remained relatively constant at CO2 pressures above 10 kPa. Furthermore, the integrated peak areas within 1076–1693 cm−1 range were plotted in Fig. 17(b). Below 10 kPa, the integrated areas increased with increasing CO2 feed pressure. However, above 10 kPa, the peak intensities remained relatively constant. These results, along with the model data, further supported the notion of carrier saturation in the facilitated transport membrane.

The carrier saturation effect presents a significant obstacle, hindering the optimal performance of FTMs especially at higher CO2 partial pressures. Recognizing this challenge is crucial as it guides future research and practical applications. The adverse impacts of carrier saturation can be mitigated by controlling the feed pressure or employing a two-stage membrane (Section 5.3).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Effect of process configuration on FTMs performance
ce:section.ce:para: Laboratory-scale prepared facilitated transport membranes are usually small in area. For practical applications, membranes sealed into modules at high packing densities and surface areas are challenging to maintain the performance of laboratory-prepared membranes [126–128]. In practical scenarios, it becomes essential to consider the permeation characteristics and selectivity of the entire membrane module rather than focusing solely on the performance of individual membranes. The design aims to minimize both the cost and energy consumption of membrane systems by optimizing membrane performance, operating conditions, and module structure, which presents a significant challenge [129].

The process using high permeance membrane in the first stage and high selectivity membrane in the second stage surpassed other combinations in terms of capture cost. Janakiram et al. compared a two-stage membrane process configuration with and without recirculation [130]. Through simulation, it was found that the usage of the higher permeance membrane (based on poly-N-isobutyl allyl amine and PVA) in the first stage and higher selectivity PVAm membrane in the second stage was the most efficient. A CO2 recovery of 90% and a purity greater than 90% could be achieved. This was confirmed in the work of Sheng et al., as shown in Fig. 18 [44]. The two-stage membrane design resulted in a very low capture cost ($44.62/tonne). And they found that this design was effective in reducing the membrane area.

The series-parallel connection of membrane blocks also has a critical impact on the separation performance of the membrane. Wu et al. designed a SW membrane module with an effective surface area of 31 m2. They tested the CO2 capture rate and purity by connecting the membrane modules in series and parallel, as shown in Fig. 19 [131]. They found that the series-parallel connection did not significantly affect the performance when three membrane modules were connected in series, as shown in Fig. 20 . When there were more membrane modules, the effects of pressure distribution and velocity distribution needed to be considered. Unlike small-area membranes typically used in laboratory settings, for larger area membranes, it is also crucial to comprehensively consider the concentration polarization [41].

While capture efficiency is vital, the capture cost is equally critical. Recently, Han et al. developed a membrane system based on FTMs [132]. It was similar to the principle of two-stage membranes, in which the first stage enriched the CO2 from the low concentration of CO2. The efficiency of separation was achieved in the second stage, in which retentate recirculation was used. The capture cost was reduced greatly, and the total capture rate reached 99% at a cost of only 47.2 USD/tonne. He et al. designed a PVAm-based membrane process that costed about 63.7 USD/tonne when the capture rate was 50%. Additionally, he found that a three-stage membrane system helped to increase the capture rate, but this increased the cost considerably [143].

Despite the academic advancements, only a few real flue gas tests have been conducted in recent years. Han et al. at The Ohio State University (OSU) tested their SW module for 500 h at the National Carbon Capture Center (NCCC) in Wilsonville, Alabama [34]. The Plate and Frame module developed by the Hägg's team was continuously tested for 6.5 months in the Nanoglowa EU project, and the membrane performance did not decrease [133]. Long term stability was obtained by the team of Han and Hägg. In addition, Dai and Janakiram obtained short-term stability in actual flue gas. Dai et al. prepared a PVA-doped amino acid salt hollow fibers membrane with a membrane area of 200 cm2 [134]. The membrane showed good performance in the first three days when it was tested in a cement plant in Gubbio, Italy, at 90 °C. However, the membrane began to show a trend of decreasing performance on the fourth day, probably due to the O2 in the raw material. The membrane's reactive sites could be oxidized. Janakiram et al. also tested HFTM hollow fiber membranes (based on polyallylamine (SHPAA)/(PVA)) containing mobile carriers at the Gubbio Cement Plant [135]. The membranes showed good performance durability over a period of two weeks.

In transitioning from laboratory-scale to practical applications of FTMs, challenges arise in maintaining performance at higher packing densities and surface areas. System-level considerations, such as module design and process configuration, are crucial for optimizing performance and minimizing costs. For example, a two-stage process with high permeance and selectivity membranes has proven cost-effective. However, the arrangement of membrane blocks can significantly impact separation performance. Real-world testing, as seen in the work of Han et al. and the Hägg's team, underscores the importance of extensive evaluations for scalability and reliability. Therefore, a focus on system design, operational optimization, and thorough testing is essential for the industrial application of FTMs.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Effect of temperature on FTMs performance
ce:section.ce:para: Temperature is also one of the key factors affecting the performance of FTMs. As the temperature increases, the mobility of the polymer chains and the diffusion rate of the gases increases, favoring higher CO2 permeance [136,137]. However, when the temperature exceeds a certain critical value, the excessively high temperature can lead to evaporation of the basic water content in the membrane, limiting the CO2 facilitated transport reaction. It may also cause changes in membrane properties, such as swelling and hydration, affecting its selectivity and stability [138,139]. Therefore, maintaining an optimal temperature range for FTMs is critical to prevent performance decreases.

In exploring the effects of temperature, Ho's team conducted multiple experiments that also included field tests. They prepared PVAm-based membranes as a fixed carrier, and amino acid salt synthesized from sarcosine with 2-(1-piperazinyl)ethylamine was used as a mobile carrier in the membrane [121]. The multi-walled carbon nanotubes were added to maintain the differential pressure. As shown in Fig. 21 (a), it was found that the feed pressure at 4 atm, the permeance of CO2 gradually increased with increasing temperature. In addition, they conducted a test of the effect of temperature (57 °C–87 °C) on the performance of their SW module at NCCC in Ohio [34]. As shown in Fig. 21 (b), they found that the temperature increase, while increasing both CO2 and N2 permeation rates, had a more significant effect on N2, so higher temperatures reduced selectivity. Furthermore, they concluded that the effect of SOX on FTMs was enhanced at higher temperatures. It is possible that the temperatures they explored were not high enough to cause rapid water evaporation. It didn't reduce the rate of CO2 penetration. Similarly, Wang's team explored the situation above 100 °C, they developed a PEI-based facilitated transport membrane [140]. They found that at temperatures below 373.15 K (100 °C), the membrane performance was stable. However, when the temperature was higher than 373.15 K (100 °C), the membrane performance decreased significantly due to the evaporation of water from the membrane.

A large number of studies have focused on CO2 permeance, which has not been conducive to fully understanding the transport process of FTMs. As shown in Fig. 22 , Ho's team explored the effect of temperature on membrane solubility [141]. The distribution of CO2 loading and reaction products (i.e., carbamate and bicarbonate) of PZEA-Sar was analyzed by 13C NMR at three temperatures (57 °C, 65 °C and 77 °C). Since the reaction between amine and CO2 is exothermic, an increase in temperature leads to a decrease in CO2 loading. Typically, an increase in temperature was accompanied by an increase in CO2 permeance. It was shown that at higher temperatures, although the decreased in CO2 solubility, the contribution from facilitated transport compensates for the decrease in CO2 permeance. Hägg's team at the Tiller plant (Trondheim, Norway) observed similar findings with FTMs based on PVAm, but did not investigate it further [33].

This review mainly summarizes the polymers applied to FTMs in the past five years and analyses the current challenges faced in this field. The main summaries and future perspectives are as follows.
(1)
FTMs, leveraging reversible chemical reactions and solution diffusion mechanisms, surpass the Roberson upper bound more effectively than traditional polymer membranes relying solely on solution diffusion mechanism.
(2)
The excellent properties of PVAm make it an ideal material for FTMs. PVAm-based FTMs offered optimistic prospects for membrane scalability and practical application. Additionally, the stability test results demonstrated the commercial viability potential of these membranes under practical conditions of flue gas exposure.
(3)
For gas separation, adapting the IP process or introducing new monomers during the preparation of PA membranes led to excellent performance. The variety of conditions for tuning the IP process provided additional research directions. The introduction of β-CD had also led to excellent stability tests. However, most studies have focused on laboratory levels or even just pure gas testing, which does not demonstrate its potential application in real flue gas environments.
(4)
In recent years, there have been limited reports on CO2 separation membranes based solely on PEI, PAA and CS. While blending several polymers improved the performance of pure polymers, there were no reports on stability under real gas testing.
(5)
The unique reaction mechanism in FTMs renders the influence of water and pressure on membrane performance significant. Maintaining water presence in the membrane is crucial for the efficient functioning of FTMs. By introducing hydrophilic polymers such as PVA, the addition of hydrophilic amino acids has improved the membrane performance. More characterization techniques have given more explanations on how water affects the FTMs process. Unlike the plasticization of the membranes based on the solution-diffusion mechanism under high pressure, the carrier saturation effect is an unavoidable problem for FTMs under high pressure. High pressure leads to dehydration of membranes, which also limits the performance of FTMs. The SERS data further confirmed the existence of the carrier saturation phenomenon. The design of suitable modules is also essential, and two-stage modules can reduce the problems associated with carrier saturation. However, it may increase energy consumption and capture costs.
(6)
Understanding the interactions between water, feed pressure and polymer structure is essential to optimize FTMs design and operating parameters for post-combustion carbon capture processes. Although the problem of decreasing membrane efficiency of FTMs at high pressures has not been well solved in recent years, combining experimental data with innovative characterization techniques can also allow understanding of these problems and provide new ideas for future solutions.

Future research can improve the efficacy and applicability of FTMs through the following pathways:
(1)
Development of new CO2 carriers and polymers: Innovative materials with higher CO2 affinity and stability under real gas conditions need to be explored. This includes the design of new monomers and optimization of polymer blends to improve membrane performance and durability.
(2)
Mechanistic studies: A deeper understanding of gas transport mechanisms within FTMs, especially under varying pressure and humidity conditions, is critical. Studying the interaction between polymer structure, CO2 carrier, and operating conditions can provide insights into overcoming challenges such as carrier saturation and membrane dehydration.
(3)
Advanced characterization techniques: Interactions in the separation process of FTMs can be revealed using advanced characterization techniques. This helps tailor membrane properties to specific applications.
(4)
Module design and process optimization: Develop efficient module designs and optimize operating parameters to mitigate issues such as carrier saturation in FTMs. Exploring two-level modules or hybrid systems may provide solutions that balance performance and energy consumption.
(5)
Long-term stability testing: Rigorous testing of FTMs under extreme conditions and long-term exposure to real flue gases is critical to assess their long-term stability and practical viability. This includes evaluating the effects of contaminants and temperature fluctuations on membrane performance.
